item.title: Government Spying Allegations in Mexico Spur Calls for Inquiry
item.media:description: Mario E. Patrón, executive director of the Miguel Augustín Pro Juárez Human Rights Center, at a news conference in Mexico City.
item.description: The calls came in response to reports saying spyware was deployed against some of the Mexican government’s most outspoken critics.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Polio Paralyzes 17 Children in Syria, W.H.O. Says
item.media:description: A health worker administered a polio vaccine in Raqqa, Syria, in November 2013.
item.description: The outbreak of the crippling disease — the second so far in Syria’s six-year-old war — was described by the World Health Organization as “very serious.”
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: The Secret Room, the Nazi Artifacts and an Argentine Mystery
item.media:description: Members of Argentinia’s federal police displayed a Nazi statue at the Interpol headquarters in Buenos Aires.
item.description: Investigators searching a home outside Buenos Aires found a door behind a bookcase, and more than 75 artifacts from the Third Reich.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Bomb Is Detonated in Brussels Train Station
item.media:description: A soldier outside Brussels Central Station on Tuesday.
item.description: The police said the situation in the Brussels Central train station was under control and that a suspect had been “neutralized.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Rewrites Succession as King Replaces Heir With Son, 31
item.media:description: Mohammed bin Salman last year in France.
item.media:credit: Stephanie De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The removal of the crown prince is a stark upheaval in the leadership of the wealthy kingdom, a key ally of the United States and the Arab world’s largest economy.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Europe Edition: Brussels, François Bayrou, Uber: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Report by Brazilian Police Ties Michel Temer to Bribery Scheme
item.media:description: President Michel Temer of Brazil in Moscow on Tuesday. He has repeatedly and vociferously denied all allegations against him.
item.description: The report by Brazil’s equivalent to the F.B.I. has intensified pressure on President Temer as he struggles to push austerity measures through Congress.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: Congolese Militia Is Accused of Atrocities
item.media:description: Food distribution this month at a camp in Kikwit, Congo, for displaced people who fled the Kasaï region.
item.description: The United Nations’ top human rights official said a militia in the Democratic Republic of Congo carried out mass killings and attacks on children and pregnant women.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Venezuela Opens Inquiry Into a Critic: Its Attorney General
item.media:description: A protester holding a copy of the Constitution and a button with the image of President Hugo Chávez at a rally against Attorney General Luisa Ortega on Monday in Caracas, the capital.
item.description: The country’s Supreme Court said it had opened an investigation into “alleged commission of serious offenses in the exercise of office” by Luisa Ortega, a critic of President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: China Falls Short on Curbing North Korea, Trump Says
item.media:description: President Trump with President Xi Jinping of China at an April summit meeting at the Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Fla.
item.description: The president’s statement was an extraordinary admission of failure of his strategy for dealing with the North, leaving him with unpalatable options.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: State Dept. Lashes Out at Gulf Countries Over Qatar Embargo
item.media:description: President Trump and Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson in May in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
item.description: The statement seemed to put President Trump and Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson further at odds about who is to blame for the dispute.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: U.N. Chief Warns U.S. of Risks of Rejecting Leadership Role
item.media:description: António Guterres, the secretary general of the United Nations, said Tuesday that he would visit Washington soon to urge lawmakers to financially support the agency.
item.description: Secretary General António Guterres said he would visit Washington soon to urge lawmakers to keep funding the United Nations and remain engaged on world issues.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: As Travel Industry Awaits Slowdown, Travelers Pack Bags — for Now
item.media:description: Travelers at Kennedy Airport in New York City early this month. The city is expecting a decline in international visitors this year.
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: In the face of restrictions, proposed travel bans and terror threats, companies are bracing for weaker growth this year, but their worst fears have not yet come to pass.
item.dc:creator: MICAH MAIDENBERG

item.title: Trump Imposes New Sanctions on Russia Over Ukraine Incursion
item.media:description: President Trump with President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine at the White House on Tuesday.
item.description: The sanctions underscored the renewed tensions with Moscow and came as the president continues to face questions about his campaign’s ties to Russia.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Georgia, Republican Party, Otto Warmbier: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Here’s One Canadian Theater Company That Isn’t Afraid to Show Off
item.media:description: Albert Schultz, the artistic director of Soulpepper Theater Company, in his office in Toronto.
item.media:credit: Ryan Enn Hughes for The New York Times
item.description: For Soulpepper Theater Company, putting on 30 productions at home won’t do this year. The Toronto troupe is also programming a New York theater center for July.
item.dc:creator: LAURA COLLINS-HUGHES

item.title: Senators Wrestle With Updating Law Authorizing War on Terrorist Groups
item.media:description: Senator Bob Corker, Republican of Tennessee and the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, spoke to reporters on Tuesday at the Capitol.
item.description: The law written after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, has long been used to justify military force against groups with tenuous links to Al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Libya’s Increased Oil Production Thwarts OPEC’s Reduction Plans
item.media:description: Oil pipelines at the port of Ras Lanuf, Libya, in January.
item.description: Despite the country’s political instability, its production has grown to 885,000 barrels a day, undercutting OPEC’s efforts to shrink supplies worldwide.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: How to Travel Safely (and Keep Calm)
item.media:description: A view of London and the River Thames from the London Eye ferris wheel.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Terrorist attacks in Britain and elsewhere may have unsettled travelers. Here are some tips to keep calm and carry on.
item.dc:creator: SHIVANI VORA

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Otto Warmbier, Syria, North Korea: Your Morning Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Germany Raids Homes of 36 People Accused of Hateful Postings Over Social Media
item.media:description: Heiko Maas, the German justice minister, is endorsing a new social media law aimed at cracking down on hate speech, a measure that an array of experts has warned is unconstitutional.
item.description: The raids were part of a coordinated campaign across 14 states. Most cases concerned politically motivated right-wing incitement, police said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SHIMER

item.title: Accused in Spying Case, Ex-Panama President Fights Extradition in Miami
item.media:description: Ricardo A. Martinelli, a former president of Panama and current member of the Central American Parliament, in 2015. He was arrested last week in Florida on illegal surveillance and embezzlement charges.
item.description: Ricardo A. Martinelli is accused of diverting $13.4 million from social programs to buy software to track business competitors and political rivals.
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: American Warplane Shoots Down Iranian-Made Drone Over Syria
item.description: The drone’s downing was the latest indication that the air war between the U.S. military and forces loyal to the Syrian government is likely to continue or even escalate.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Killing of 8 Afghan Guards Shows Bitter Change at Bagram
item.media:description: Afghan Army soldiers blocked a road to the main gate of the United States military base in Bagram after a suicide bombing by a local member of staff in November. Hundreds of Afghan workers at the base were laid off after the attack, and tighter restrictions were placed on those who remained.
item.description: Jobs at the sprawling American military base were once highly coveted. No longer, as a Taliban attack on off-duty staff late on Monday highlighted.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR, FAHIM ABED and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Paris Journal: With Acrobats and Cake, a Paris Opera Celebrates Its Rebirth
item.media:description: A view of the Opéra Comique in Paris after its renovation.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The newly renovated Opéra Comique draws on opera’s rich history of innovation — and circus acrobats — in an effort to appeal to modern Parisians.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: How Neighbors Saw Man Held in London Mosque Attack: ‘Drunk, Cursing and Vile’
item.media:description: A vigil outside the Finsbury Park Mosque in North London on Monday.
item.description: Residents said that Darren Osborne was often agitated, even disturbed, but few described him as frightening and none said he had expressed political sentiments — until last weekend.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: As Sailors’ Bodies Are Flown to U.S., Fitzgerald Inquiries Intensify
item.media:description: The damaged American destroyer Fitzgerald near the American naval base at Yokosuka, Japan.
item.description: The United States Navy and Coast Guard, and the Japanese authorities, ramped up their investigations in the collision of a cargo vessel and an American warship.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Russia’s ‘Gay Propaganda’ Laws Are Illegal, European Court Rules
item.media:description: Police officers detained Nikolai A. Alekseyev during an unauthorized protest in 2013 against Russian laws banning the promotion or display of homosexuality.
item.description: The statutes are discriminatory, violated freedom of expression and “served no legitimate public interest,” the court found.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Otto Warmbier’s Death a New Wedge Between U.S. and North Korea
item.media:description: Otto Warmbier being transferred from an airplane to an ambulance at Lunken Airport in Cincinnati last week. He died on Monday.
item.description: Some analysts said anger over the death would heighten tensions, but others said the White House was unlikely to let the case upset the momentum toward dialogue.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Reviving a French Opera
item.description: Step into “Alcyone,” an 18th-century French opera that had not been performed in Paris for 246 years.

item.title: Inside an Iraqi Major’s Battle Against ISIS
item.description: Ben C. Solomon, a Times video journalist, tells the story of Major Sajjad al-Hour as he leads 150 men through the war-torn streets of Mosul.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
